title: What is a DataFest Mentor?
text:
Are you or someone you know interested in serving as a mentor or judge for ASA DataFest 2025 at Cal Poly? Fill out the following form to be contacted: xxx.

What is a DataFest Mentor?


Serving as a DataFest Judge

title: ASA DataFest @ Cal Poly - SLO
text:
How big are teams?
While teams can be between 2-5 individuals, teams with 4-5 individuals will be given priority over teams with fewer. If you have a team of 3 and there is an individual without a team, they may be added to your team at last minute.


 What if I don’t have a team?
We will send out an interest form before official team sign up and do our best to connect you with other students who are looking to form a team. Additionally, we will hold a DataFest Social Mixer where you can come learn more about DataFest and chat with other potential teammates.


 When will we find out about the data?
The data and context is released during DataFest Kickoff on Friday at 5pm of the event weekend. It is kept secret until then!


 Can we work overnight?
The official work space will close at 10 p.m., but you are welcome to find a space in the campus union or library to work overnight. The official work space will open again the next morning at 8 a.m. All work MUST be completed on Cal Poly premises.


 What is the final deliverable?
Each team will have 5 minutes to present their findings to a panel of three judges.
Each team will be allowed at most three slides. Three. So at some point on Sunday, you might want to set aside time to think about what you want the judges to know. The 5 minute time limit will be strictly enforced. All team members must be present for the presentation, but not all team members need to actually speak (given the time limitation).
Awards will be given in three categories:

Best in Show: This is the main prize.
Best Visualization
Best Use of Outside Data

Winners will receive mini trophies with the event and award name as well as a free ASA membership.
While there is a judging and award portion of this event, we encourage a fun and friendly environment for all to learn!


 Are you accepting teams from other institutions?
We do not currently have a mechanism in place to host other teams at Cal Poly for DataFest. Our pipe dream is in the next few years to expand to a Central Coast DataFest. If your institution is interested in working with us to make this happen, please contact us at statisticsdepartment@calpoly.edu.

title: What is DataFest?
text:
What is DataFest?
DataFest is a national event organized by the American Statistical Association as a celebration of data in which teams of undergraduates work around the clock to find and share meaning in a large, rich, and complex data set. The ASA provides a data set to participating institutions in which local DataFests are held across the country during March and April each year.
 Intense Collaboration: Teams of 2-5 undergraduates engage in a 48-hour data analysis marathon, working to decipher a complex data set and craft insightful solutions.
 Innovation and Camaraderie: Participants are fueled by a spirit of innovation and teamwork, pushing the boundaries of data exploration while fostering a supportive and collaborative environment.
 Showcasing Discoveries: The event culminates in 5-minute presentations where teams share their findings and insights. Awards are given for the Best in Show, Best Visualization, and Best Use of Outside Data.
Learn more at https://ww2.amstat.org/education/datafest/.

title: ASA DataFest @ Cal Poly - SLO
text:
2024
 10 Teams
 3 Colleges at Cal Poly
 1 Data Set
A total of 39 undergraduate students participated in a weekend of visualizing, summarizing, and analyzing data about an online statistics textbook. Students participated from across three colleges including: mostly Statistics & Data Science major in the Bailey College of Science and Technology, a handful of Computer Science majors in the College of Engineering, and a couple of students completing the Quantitative Concentration from the Orfalea College of Business.






Best in Show: (left) Cameron Stivers, Anagha Sikha, Kirina Sirohi, and Rachel Roggenkemper







Best Visualization: (left) Alea Seifert, Jett Palmer, Kaatja Matthews-vanKoetsveld, and Alie Hall







Best Use of Outside Data: (left) Charlie Ray, Seth Johnson, Billie Block, and Deven Singh





Read more about our first in-person DataFest at First In-Person DataFest Held at Cal Poly: Tackling Complex Problems in Teams by Nick Wilson.
